MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Famine in Ethiopia.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy De Rossa and Deputy G. Mitchell have been given permission to raise a matter on the Adjournment. Each Deputy has four minutes and the Minister has four minutes.

The subject matter is, to ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs the steps he proposes to take to remedy the unsatisfactory situation whereby food is allowed to accumulate in intervention in the EC while children starve in the Third World. It concerns hunger in Ethiopia.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: Because time is short I will move along. It would be a very hard-hearted person who has not been moved by recent reports which have conveyed such a vivid picture of the appalling level of suffering now being endured as a result of famine in Ethiopia. We have seen the film of children in the final stages of starvation with their swollen stomachs and faces like those of old men, and men and women stunned and defeated, drifting listlessly, broken by the extent of their want. It is hard for us to comprehend the extent of the problem now being faced in Ethiopia, particularly in the northern provinces of Tigre and Wollo. According to the Ethiopian Government and international relief agencies, up to two million people have had to leave their homes as a result of the famine, thousands are dying each day and as many as five million people face the prospect of starvation. That is more than the entire population on this island.

Deputy Wilson speaking in a debate today said that nature had been very good to Ireland, and that is so. It must be admitted that nature has been very bad to Ethiopia and has not been good to it in any recent year. There was a dreadful famine there in 1972 and again in 1974. Even at the best of times the average Ethiopian has an annual income of less than £50 and a life expectancy of less than 39 years. Poverty and hunger, I suppose, could be said accurately to be a way of death in Ethiopia, but the situation has deteriorated to such an extent that it demands immediate action by those countries, including Ireland, which, whatever their problems, are more fortunate than so many Third World countries.

MainHeading.P: There are a number of specific things I should like to ask the Government to do and the country to support. The first request I should like to make is that the Government immediately, from our own resources under our own bilateral aid programme, make a substantial amount of money available for relief. Because of the internal political problems within Ethiopia it is preferable that this money should be allocated through Irish non-governmental organisations, such as Trocaire, who are working in those parts of Ethiopia where its own government cannot reach. Secondly, I should like to ask the Government, in their capacity as President of the EC Council of Ministers, to ensure that the Community reacts immediately to this problem with a substantial donation of cash and food, particularly cereals. The Government should attempt to have EC bureaucracy by-passed because, as I understand it, it can take four or five months between the receipt of a an appeal to the EC and the delivery of food.

My third point is that the Government should ensure that there is an intensified effort under the European Development Fund to provide the backup services in terms of agricultural development, irrigation, health and so on so that the overall problems of hunger can be tackled. It is a necessity to ensure that aid is not in any way withheld for political reasons. The Government should urge all countries with major air fleets to respond to the appeal by the Ethopian Government for air transport. I should like to ask the Minister to request Aer Lingus, who often have spare capacity in winter months, to make it available to the Ethiopian relief effort.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Tonight's Question on the Adjournment relates to a motion I have tabled which has become urgent because of the situation in Ethiopia. We should be aware that this famine, the worst in 20 years, does not effect Ethiopia alone. In fact, it affects 24 countries in the sub-Saharan south Africa. We should concern ourselves with this problem because we have a responsibility to do something about it. I appeal to the Minister to take urgent action at national and European level to ensure that something is done. The fact that there is some distance between Ireland and southern Africa does not take from the fact that many children are starving. Those of us with young children should consider what it would be like if our children's stomachs bulged with hunger. It is an unbelievable problem in that country and the only thing that is putting it away from us is the question of distance. However, it is only an air flight away and we must try to sort the problem out.

We can help by transferring some surplus goods in the EC to Ethiopia but in itself that will not solve the problem. It will contribute to the immediate relief particularly if the surplus is in the form of cereals. There is a problem of a fall in foreign aid, particularly from the United States. There is also a problem in regard to foreign exchange rates and of drought. In our Programme for Government we gave commitments to pay £64 million per year but we are only paying £46 million per year. Even the commitments in the recently published national plan do not bring us to the £64 million per year. We cannot ignore our commitments to those people. If we want to see a free world where people will respect the rights of others we have to ensure that the environment is right for those people to survive. It would take 650,000 tons of grain to assist the people for one year in Ethiopia alone.

MainHeading.P: In the Western world we are continuously reneging on our commitments to countries in southern Africa. It should be said that by and large the Government's of some of those countries are military Governments and they are reneging on their responsibilities to their citizens. In many cases funds supplied for food are used for military purposes. We need to provide money for infrastructure so that people can trap water. We need to give them money so that they can store grain, a simple thing. It is our wealth that we need to send, not our surplus. I appeal to the Minister to urgently arrange for bilateral action. This requires action immediately. We need to declare tonight that the Government will send relief funds to the stricken regions. As President of the EC we should call an urgent meeting of the Council of Ministers and ask other member states to take similar action individually and as a Community. I am pleading with the Minister to decide now to give extra bilateral aid by way of emergency disaster funds to assist those people. How can we go away from here and eat or drink without meeting such a commitment? I appeal to the Minister to meet my suggestion.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: On behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and the Minister of State who are both away, I should like to state that all Members share the concern expressed by Deputies De Rossa and Mitchell in regard to the appalling tragedy that is taking place in Ethiopia. Indeed, tragedies of a similar nature although, possibly, not on quite the same scale are taking place throughout the continent of Africa generally. That continent has suffered from an unusual drought in recent years and there is a grave shortage of food. I share the concern of the Deputies that we, blessed as we are by nature's bounty in comparison to those other countries, should be doing everything possible to contribute to the alleviation of this awful suffering, that we should be doing it out of our own resources and that we should be using our position as a member of the EC and as President of that group to encourage the maximum mobilisation of EC aid.

I should like to assure the House that we are doing everything possible in both areas. All EC countries individually are making substantial contributions to the problem in Ethiopia. The Community, as a Community, is also heavily involved. Already 19,000 tonnes of grain have been sent to Ethiopia this year and a further 25,000 tonnes of grain are being prepared for shipment in coming weeks and up to and including the Christmas period.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Is that from Ireland?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: From the EC. A total of 1,800 tonnes of milk powder, allied with that 640 tonnes of butter oil — apparently the two are used together in a process to provide food — and 500 tonnes of vegetable oil will be sent from the Community to Ethiopia over the next couple of weeks and up to and after Christmas.

The EC do care and have a lot of knowledge and expertise on the accumulation of aid, transporting of it and, above all, in the distribution of aid. The logistics of assembling, transporting and distributing aid in these countries is of itself an immense problem. The logistics require a great deal of funding. In fact, it is of critical importance that a lot of the funds available for famine relief would be spent not just on food but on streamlining the logistics for distributing that food. A lot of the EC financial contribution goes in that direction. There is no point in having thousands of tonnes of grain stored at ports in Europe or, as is happening, and has happened, stored at ports in the African continent and at depots within that continent but not being distributed. That is the real tragedy, to have help so near and not get it out. A lot of the EC effort is directed towards ensuring that the aid that is available gets to the people who need it.

MainHeading.P: I should like to assure the House that I take seriously the points made by the Deputies who spoke. From our own resources we have made substantial contributions already this year. We will be making further contributions in the latter part of the year. Extra sums are being provided for our disaster aid fund. To take the point that Deputy De Rossa made, we are taking advantage of the efficiency of our non-governmental organisations and we avail of them. In particular, we avail of Christian Aid, Concern and an ad hoc group called the Third World Self Help Development Organisation, which has come together. We are funding them to assist them in their work in that area. In addition the IFA are making available grain to the value of £50,000 and the Government will be providing the logistics to get that grain sent to Ethiopia. The Minister of State, who is in Strasbourg at present, is acutely aware of the need to mobilise the EC as a Community. In fairness to the Community it must be said that he is pushing an open door as far as a response is concerned. The House can be assured that on a national basis, and from our position as President of the EC, we will do all we possibly can to alleviate this awful suffering we have seen so graphically portrayed on our television screens recently.
The Dáil adjourned at 9 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Thursday, 25 October 1984.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Noraid Fund Raising.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if in view of the fact that the main source of IRA funds continues to be the USA he will consider a new and stronger publicity campaign to counter the activities of fund-raising groups in that country and to explain more fully to the US public the true position in Northern Ireland and the aims and objectives of the constitutional nationalist parties on this island.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: The Government have made great efforts, through all available means, to counter the activities of Noraid and other American groups which seek to raise funds in support of terrorism in Ireland. These efforts are an integral part of our campaign to reach out to Irish Americans and explain to them the realities of the Northern Ireland problem and the efforts which are being made by constitutional nationalists towards achieving a solution. The visit of the Taoiseach to the US for St. Patrick's Day and President Reagan's visit here in June focused tremendous interest in the US on these issues. Both leaders availed of the visits to explicitly condemn those Americans who provide moral or financial support for violence in Ireland.

MainHeading.P: Last month in New York I met Irish American leaders to tell them what our Government are doing to achieve a solution in Northern Ireland and to protect the interests and well-being of the nationalist community there. I also told them that the activities of Noraid have done nothing but promote the campaign of violence and open wounds in a horribly tense and fragile situation. I expressed to them my wish that the adverse impression of Irish-Americans that has been created among some people in Ireland by small unrepresentative groups like Noraid should be actively countered by the vast majority of Irish Americans who I know are opposed to the IRA campaign of murder, destruction and hatred in our country.

It is indeed important to remember that only a tiny minority of the 40 million Irish-Americans are in any way supportive of violence in Ireland or of IRA front organisations like Noraid. This is a point I emphasised in an article condemning Noraid which I wrote in August for a US nationwide daily, USA Today. I used that article to explain to a wide audience in the US why the Irish Government condemned the Noraid visit to Ireland earlier that month. In addition in an interview I gave to the Irish Echo, a leading Irish-American newspaper, last month concerning Noraid and similar groups I stated that “no single factor has more impeded the unity and reconciliation of the Irish people than the murderous sectarian campaign of the Provisional IRA”.

Both the Taoiseach and I have given interviews in recent weeks to major US television networks to press home the message that no American should contribute to subversive front organisations, such as Noraid. These direct appeals to the Irish-American community and to the American public in general have a significant impact and help to isolate the small number who fund violence.

Noraid and other US groups continue to be one of a number of important sources of funds for the Provisional IRA. The Government is committed to ensuring that its views regarding a peaceful solution are fully understood by Irish-Americans who at the same time have been left in no doubt about our total condemnation of Noraid and any other groups which support terrorist violence in this country. The success of our efforts to date has been clearly demonstrated in the overwhelming condemnation by the American media of the IRA and its support groups in the US following the seizure of the Marita Ann and the outrage at Brighton. These most recent murderous activities by subversives serve to reinforce the determination of the Government to expose the true nature of those sympathiser groups in the US to which the Deputy has referred.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The North-Western Health Board recently completed a comprehensive study of the mentally handicapped population and the services provided and available to that population in the region. The results of that study will be published shortly.

The board's philosophy and policy in relation to the provision of residential care for the mentally handicapped, with the exception of short-term care/ temporary relief, is that it should only be offered and available as a last resort after all other alternatives such as family support and hostel accommodation have proved unsuitable.

The present position is that there are 20 adults waitlisted for admission to residential centres in the board's area. However, it is anticipated that only a small number will eventually require residential care and that the remainder will continue to live in their respective communities with all the necessary support services provided. Only one child is waitlisted for residential care and a place will be offered to that child in due course. In the meantime, pending placement in residential care, periods of short-term relief are available to this child's family.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason in many cases single persons living with their family have means assessed against them for unemployment assistance purposes, thereby encouraging many of them to leave home in order to qualify for the full amount of unemployment assistance and whether he feels that the current means assessment policy in such cases is fair.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: Under the legislation governing the scheme of unemployment assistance the value of the benefit which an applicant derives from board and lodgings in his parents' home must be taken into account as means. The amount assessed for this purpose depends on the income of the parents in each individual case. This arrangement ensures that a degree of equity is achieved as between an applicant whose parents are in relatively better off circumstances and an applicant whose circumstances are poor.

The means test for unemployment assistance is designed to ensure that all applicants for unemployment assistance are treated in an equitable manner having regard to the resources available to them and as operated it is a fair and reasonable method of determining entitlement and allocating scarce resources to those in greatest need.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if exchanges of land will be considered in future, when land is being divided by the Land Commission.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Exchanges of land are a normal feature of Land Commission activities and are an essential factor in the rearrangement of fragmented holdings.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Brennan Mr. M. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture when it is expected that the sheep headage grants for 1984 will be paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Payments of 1984 sheep headage grants in the disadvantaged areas will commence this week.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will outline his policy regarding Christmas parole for long-term prisoners, particularly those who have already served considerable periods of nine years or more in prison without any time out; and if he will detail the criteria involved in making a decision regarding Christmas parole.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The sentences of all long-term offenders are kept under continuing review, notably at the interdisciplinary review meetings in the various prisons and places of detention. Factors taken into account in considering whether home leave which, of course, includes leave at Christmas, should be recommended in the case of an offender, include the length of time served, the offenders performance as regards work and conduct within the prison, and the likely risk to the community in the event of the offender's release.
Each offender is given details of his temporary release programme when it has been approved.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if the long delayed disciplinary proceedings against a person (details supplied) have been finally concluded; and the outcome.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): Under the terms of the Garda Síochána (Discipline) Regulations, 1971, the conduct of disciplinary proceedings is a matter for the Garda Commissioner.

I am informed by the Commissioner that the disciplinary proceedings in this case were concluded in December 1983. It has never been the practice for the Garda authorities in cases of this nature to disclose publicly decisions taken in disciplinary proceedings which, under the statutory regulations, are required to be held in private. The member concerned has since retired from the force.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. V. Brady Mr. V. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when a decision will issue regarding a fine imposed on a person (details supplied) in Dublin 5.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I refer the Deputy to a letter dated 18 October 1984 conveying my decision to him in this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position regarding the proposed extension to a school (details supplied) in County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department have agreed to the extension and reconstruction of the school referred to with a view to providing six suitable classrooms, a general purposes room and ancillary accommodation. The Commissioners of Public Works have been requested to prepare sketch plans for the project. My Department will be in touch with the school authorities as soon as the plans become available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position on the appointment of a remedial teacher to schools (details supplied) in County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The application of the schools in question for a remedial teaching post is currently being considered in the context of the priority of need in the schools generally and the availability of remedial posts for the 1984-85 school year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when additional accommodation will be provided at Fintra national school, Killybegs, County Donegal, in respect of which sketch plans were submitted to her Department by the Office of Public Works some 12 months ago.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The Commissioners of Public Works have been asked to prepare revised sketch plans for the additional accommodation proposed for Fintra national school, County Donegal. When the revised plans come to hand my Department will be in touch with the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether it is her Department's intention to amalgamate second-level schools in Ballyshannon, County Donegal; and on what grounds this is being done.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when the necessary repairs will be carried out to De La Salle College, Ballyshannon, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 564 and 565 together.

A major post primary school building programme including the provision of a new school to replace the De La Salle College is proposed for Ballyshannon. In accordance with the terms of the Programme for Action in Education 1984-87 (paragraph 5.12), it is necessary to examine the practicability of the integration or, alternatively, the co-ordination of post-primary school facilities in the Ballyshannon catchment area. Pending completion of this examination, it is not possible to indicate what proposals if any my Department will make to the local school authorities in relation to the future development of post-primary education facilities in Ballyshannon. Neither is it possible at this stage to say when the new De La Salle College will be provided. It is hoped that it will be possible to make decisions in these matters at an early date.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding the proposal to build a new second-level school at Sixmilebridge, County Clare; and if she will meet a deputation of parents and public representatives from the area to discuss the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: County Clare Vocational Education Committee sought permission in 1983 to buy a site for a community college at Sixmilebridge. My Department considers a new post-primary school at Sixmilebridge unnecessary and did not accede to the request. There are sufficient places for pupils from the area in post primary schools in Shannon, Ennis, Tulla and Limerick where they traditionally attend.

My Department understand that a group of parents are at present compiling a submission on the matter which I assume will be forwarded to my Department. When this submission is received I will consider the request for a meeting referred to in the Deputy's question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when improvement works will be carried out on a school (details supplied) in County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department have agreed to a comprehensive scheme of improvements, including an extension, for the school referred to by the Deputy and the Commissioners of Public Works have been asked to prepare the necessary sketch scheme. My Department will be in touch with the school authorities as soon as the scheme comes to hand.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if, in view of the special circumstances which exist, she will reexamine the application by the board of management of Brookfield community school, Tallaght, Dublin 24, to have school transport provided for the pupils attending Brookfield community school which is operating at present from Killinarden community school, Tallaght.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: As the pupils in question live within three miles of the post-primary school they attend, they are not eligible for school transport under the terms of the post-primary school transport scheme. In the circumstances, it would not be open to my Department to sanction special transport arrangements for these pupils.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Tallaght (County Dublin) Primary School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if the request to have a new boundary fence provided at the new primary school at Brookfield, Tallaght, Dublin 24, has been approved by her Department; and, if so, when the fencing will be erected.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: On 8 October 1984 my Department sanctioned a grant for the provision of security fencing at the Brookfield national schools, Tallaght, Dublin 24. The erection of the fencing is a matter for the school authorities in consultation with the Commissioners of Public Works.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Dublin Community Project.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will provide funds for the proposed Firhouse community complex, in view of the substantial local effort being made by the public.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: There are no funds available to my Department at present whereby capital grant assistance can be made available to projects of this nature. However, as indicated in Building on Reality 1985-87, the Government have decided that funds will be made available over the period to enable grant aid to be provided towards the cost of building recreational and community facilities. The terms and conditions governing the allocation of grants under this scheme will be announced shortly and interested groups including the Firhouse Community Council will be invited to make application to my Department for grant aid.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Drogheda Employment Statistics.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bell Mr. Bell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the number of people in full-time employment each year for the last ten years in the town of Drogheda (male and female) the amount of new jobs created during this period each year; and the number of redundancies that have occurred over the same period.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: As regards the first part of the question, the only information available in relation to Drogheda would be in the censuses of population carried out by the Central Statistics Office. I understand the relevant figures relating to the 1981 census are expected to be published in a few months.

Information available on job creation is confined to manufacturing industry and is supplied by the IDA on the basis of their employment survey. I hope that the information, which is as follows, will be helpful to the Deputy:

MainHeading.P: The figures are for all jobs gained including first time jobs, and do not allow for jobs lost.

Statistics of redundancies notified under the Redundancy Payments Acts compiled in my Department are not broken down into geographical areas. Monthly statistics of proposed redundancies notified are compiled on a countrywide basis and categorised by industrial sector and sex. I regret that it would not be practicable to extract statistics relating to particular towns, such as Drogheda.
